title-group.article-title: Holocene palaeoenvironmental change and the impact of prehistoric salt production in the Seille Valley, eastern France

author-notes.corresp: Naomi G Riddiford, Department of Geography, Royal Holloway, University of London, Egham TW20 0EX UK. Email: naomi.riddiford.2005@live.rhul.ac.uk

abstract.p: The Seille Valley in eastern France was home to one of Europe’s largest Iron Age salt industries. Sedimentology, palynology and geochronology have been integrated within ongoing archaeological investigations to reconstruct the Holocene palaeoenvironmental history of the Seille Valley and to elucidate the human–environment relationship of salt production. A sedimentary model of the valley has been constructed from a borehole survey of the floodplain and pollen analyses have been undertaken to reconstruct the vegetation history. Alluvial records have been successfully dated using optically stimulated luminescence and radiocarbon techniques, thereby providing a robust chronological framework. The results have provided an insight into the development of favourable conditions for salt production and there is evidence in the sedimentary record to suggest that salt production may have taken place during the mid-to-late Bronze Age. The latter has yet to be identified in the archaeological record and targeted excavation is therefore underway to test this finding. The development of the Iron Age industry had a major impact on the hydrological regime of the valley and its sedimentological history, with evidence for accelerated alluviation arising from floodplain erosion at salt production sites and modification of the local fluvial regime due to briquetage accumulation on the floodplain. This research provides an important insight into the environmental implications of early industrial activities, in addition to advancing knowledge about the Holocene palaeoenvironmental and social history of this previously poorly studied region of France.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Prehistoric salt production has been the subject of global archaeological investigations and there is a remarkable similarity in the physical evidence for this activity (e.g. Alexander, 1975; Brown, 1980; Chen, 2008; Flad, 2003; Kondo, 1975; Lane and Morris, 2001; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006; Potts, 1984). Salt production was first recognised in the archaeological record of the Seille Valley (eastern France) at the beginning of the 20th century. Large accumulations of broken crudely fired clay artefacts (‘briquetage’), ash, charcoal and structural remains such as furnaces were found in proximity to saline springs at this locality (Keune, 1901) and these deposits bore remarkable similarity to those identified at a number of other coastal and inland sites (e.g. Stopes, 1879; Voss, 1901; Wilmer, 1908). Research confirmed that the deposits were derived from processes involving the application of fire and heat to separate salt crystals from brine solutions (saline springs and sea water) (Bertaux, 1987; Fielding, 2005a; Langouët et al., 1994; Tijani and Loehnert, 2004). Investigations have largely focused on trying to decipher the complex archaeology associated with these sites and whilst much has begun to be revealed about salt production and its role in prehistoric society, important questions remain (Bell et al., 1999; Fawn et al., 1990; Lane and Morris, 2001). These relate to the scale and technology of production, the chronology of this activity and its impact on the local environment.

The Seille Valley is one of the most intensively studied prehistoric salt production sites in Europe (Arteze de la Sauvagere, 1740; Beaupre, 1901; Bertaux, 1972a, 1972b, 1972c, 1976, 1987; Deyber, 1972; Keune, 1901; Olivier, 2001, 2004, 2007, 2009; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006, 2007). The current research project, which began in 2001, has integrated archaeology and palaeoenvironmental investigations to address the issues identified above. This approach has been adopted in recognition that the environmental context of these sites is pivotal to understanding the activity, the people involved and their relationship with the local environment. Archaeological investigations (magnetic and multifrequency electromagnetism surveys, excavation, and relative and radiocarbon dating) have begun to ascertain the spatial organisation and chronology of the salt workshops as well as the likely production processes and technologies employed (Olivier, 2009; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006, 2007). This research has demonstrated that the Seille Valley contains the remains of one of Europe’s largest and most important Iron Age salt industries spanning the 8th–1st centuries bc (~2750–2050 cal. BP) (Figure 1) and the scale of production is likely to have exerted a significant impact on the local environment: salt was harvested in enormous quantities, as evident from the ~3–4 million m3 of briquetage identified on the floodplain in deposits up to 12 m thick and 0.5 km across (Olivier, 2009; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006). It has however been difficult to date the onset of salt production with certainty as there are areas of the floodplain where briquetage accumulation began at considerable depths, well beyond the limits of conventional excavation.

sec.p: This paper presents the findings of palaeoenvironmental investigations in the Seille Valley, where sedimentology, palynology and geochronology have been employed to:

list-item.p: reconstruct the Holocene environmental history of the Seille Valley;
identify evidence for the onset of prehistoric salt production in the environmental record; and

determine the relationship between past human activities and local environmental change, and to assess the impact of these activities, with emphasis on the period corresponding to prehistoric salt production.

sec.p: This research has permitted the development of favourable environmental conditions for salt production to be investigated. It has resulted in a new methodology for dating prehistoric salt production sites, integrating optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) and radiocarbon techniques, and there is tentative evidence for Bronze Age salt production which has yet to be identified in the wider archaeological record. Whilst there are still challenges to overcome in reconciling the environmental chronology with that of the archaeology, the palaeoenvironmental record does provide an important insight into the impact of salt production and its relationship with environmental change, in addition to advancing knowledge about the Holocene environmental and social history of a previously poorly studied region of France.

sec.title: Study site
sec.p: The Seille Valley (32N 315000, 540700; elevation 205 m above sea level (m a.s.l.)) forms part of the Upper Moselle Basin, a subcatchment of the Rhine. The River Seille is approximately 140 km long and flows between Dieuze and Metz, draining an area of ~1290 km2. The catchment is underlain by impermeable saliferous lower Keuper marl to a maximum depth of ~150–200 m (Boidin et al., 2005) and capped seasonally variable saline aquifers are widespread, ranging in depth from ~30 m to 150 m (Goguel, 1959). The region is characterised by a dense network of rivers, streams and lakes, and brine springs are common (Marchal et al., 1972).

The present study focuses on the upper reaches of the River Seille between Mulcey and Burthecourt, a 12 km stretch of the valley that corresponds to the distribution of salt archaeology (Figure 1). Brine springs have a salt content of ~11.5% solution at this locality, three to four times the concentration of sea water. Saline groundwater has been identified close to the floodplain surface (<1 m depth) at a number of sites, including Marsal and Vic-sur-Seille, where salt-rich lower Keuper marl is directly overlain by permeable drift deposits. Brine springs are particularly abundant in such areas of ‘wet rock head’ (Nevell, 2005; Woodiwiss, 1992), as well as at the base of middle Keuper outcrops of dolomite and sandstone in the Seille Valley (Goguel, 1959; Marchal et al., 1972). This distribution coincides with the location of Iron Age salt workshops (Figure 1). A similar relationship has been identified between Mercia Mudstone (Keuper marl) geology and the location of Iron Age and Roman salt archaeology in Cheshire (UK) (Connelly and Power, 2005; Garner, 2005; Nevell, 2005; Woodiwiss, 1992) and this may therefore be a useful indicator for identifying possible early salt production sites.

Within the study area the Seille Valley has an east to west down-valley gradient and the floodplain ranges in width from 750 m at Marsal in the east, narrowing downstream to 250 m at Salonnes in the west. The modern river floods periodically, particularly during the winter when the entire floodplain is inundated for months at a time. Around 6 m of alluvium (predominantly silt and clay with some sand and gravel) has accumulated during the Holocene, compared with a total average depth of 1 to 4 m in equivalent subcatchments of the Rhine (Hoffmann et al., 2007). This suggests that there has been anomalous alluviation in the Seille Valley, and there is also a substantial depth of colluvium (~2 m) on the valley sides. Together these sediments have buried at least two Pleistocene terraces, which formed during the Weischelian glaciation when the River Seille was influenced by periglacial conditions in the Upper Moselle Basin (Cordier et al., 2006). These environmental factors have led to the development of naturally well-drained loessic soils on valley-side slopes and parts of the valley floor, but saltmarsh occurs in the vicinity of brine springs and freshwater marsh is found adjacent to the River Seille. Historical records indicate that extensive drainage of the floodplain and modifications to the River Seille have taken place from at least the Medieval Period onwards, with the river adopting its modern course in the 19th century following canalisation (de Martimprey de Romécourt, 1887; Decomps, 2003).

The Seille Valley has a long association with salt production. During the Iron Age it rose to prominence as a premier European industrial salt production centre and the remains of this activity dominate the archaeological record. Briquetage ‘islands’ ranging in size from 1 m thick × 50 m long to 12 m thick × 500 m long are present on the floodplain (Olivier, 2007; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006). The urban centres of Marsal, Moyenvic and Vic-sur-Seille were established on the largest of these from the Roman period onwards (Olivier and Kovacik, 2006). Furnaces have been identified in continuous alignments over hundreds of meters (Olivier and Kovacik, 2006, 2007) and the scale of archaeological remains greatly surpasses those of contemporary northwest European sites (Bizien-Jaglin, 1995; Fawn et al., 1990; Fielding, 2005a; Garner, 2005; Jülich, 2005; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006; Tessier, 1975). Domestic pottery found in association with briquetage and structural remains have been used to establish a relative chronology and this has been supplemented by radiocarbon dating of charcoal associated with production debris (Olivier, 2009). During the early Iron Age (8th to 6th centuries bc) there were around ten production centres on the floodplain, ranging between 1 and 4 ha in size (Olivier and Kovacik, 2006). As the technology evolved, production intensified and became focused at Marsal, Moyenvic and Vic-sur-Seille, peaking in the late Iron Age (2nd to 1st centuries bc) (Olivier, 2009; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006). Production continued with the arrival of the Romans and the introduction of new techniques (e.g. metal evaporation pans) and the final salt works closed in 1973 (Decomps, 2003).

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A borehole survey was conducted to construct a sedimentary model of the floodplain. Fifty boreholes were put down using a Stitz piston corer in a series of cross-valley transects, the most detailed of which was obtained from Marsal (Figure 1). This locality was chosen for in-depth investigation due to its direct proximity to Iron Age salt workshops and the potential it therefore offered to assess the relationship between salt production and environmental change. This has been made possible by the presence of briquetage archaeology in the sedimentary sequence (Figure 2). The sequence also highlights other facies units common to the majority of boreholes surveyed and there is good overall continuity between cross-valley profiles. This investigation has enabled a sedimentary model to be devised for the Seille Valley. To add further detail to the model, lithostratigraphic analyses were conducted on selected borehole core samples from Marsal and Salonnes. Salonnes was chosen due to its distal location from major salt production centres (Figure 1), increasing the chance of obtaining an undisturbed sedimentary record from which the broad vegetation history of the valley could be derived. Samples for organic matter and calcium carbonate content were taken at 4 cm intervals from Marsal and Salonnes sediment cores using the Bengtsson and Enell (1990) method. Samples for magnetic susceptibility were taken at 3 cm intervals using a Bartington MS2C core loop sensor following procedures outlined by Walden (1999) and Dearing (1999).

The transect cuts directly through salt archaeology (briquetage), which accumulated next to furnaces used in the evaporation process (see also Figure 1 for the location of workshop areas). (b) Marsal cross-valley profile drawn at a 1:1 vertical scale. The position and identification code of each borehole core sample are indicated along the top of these profiles.

sec.p: In order to reconstruct the vegetation history of the valley, samples for pollen analysis were taken every 16 cm from a long and relatively undisturbed Holocene sedimentary sequence obtained from the centre of the floodplain at Salonnes (BH15: Figure 1). Two years previously another borehole, BH2, had been put down at this location (no more than 2 m away from BH15) and a preliminary pollen record constructed (Twiddle, 2004). This study confirmed the potential of this site for reconstructing vegetation history. BH24 at Marsal (Figure 2) was also analysed for pollen prior to and during the period corresponding to prehistoric salt production (identified from the sedimentary sequence and chronology at this locality) in an attempt to yield information about localised impacts on vegetation at salt production sites. Samples were initially taken at 16 cm intervals, increasing to 8 cm in sediment deposited following the onset of salt production. Pollen extraction and mounting procedures conformed to Royal Holloway Geography Department guidelines (Branch, 2000), adapted from Moore et al. (1991). A Lycopodium spike was added to each sample to permit calculation of pollen concentration (Benninghoff, 1962) and a total pollen count of 300 grains (excluding aquatics, spores and indeterminable pollen) was used in this study.

Pollen preservation and concentration were variable throughout the Salonnes and Marsal samples. Identifiable grains were recorded as either well-preserved or degraded, depending on level of preservation. Indeterminable grains were subdivided into degraded, crumpled and broken (Cushing, 1967; Lowe, 1982). Together this allowed taphonomic factors affecting the pollen records to be assessed. Zonation of the pollen records was achieved using constrained incremental sum of squares cluster analysis (CONISS (Grimm, 1987); see also Birks and Berglund, 1979, and Birks, 1986a). Local pollen assemblage zones (LPAZs) were identified following critical assessment of the resultant dendrogram and known ecological relationships between taxa.

A coordinated programme of radiocarbon and OSL dating was undertaken to resolve the question of when salt production began in the Seille Valley and to link the archaeological record with the sedimentary model and palaeoenvironmental records from Marsal and Salonnes. OSL dating has the advantage of overcoming problems arising from the radiocarbon plateau at the beginning of the Iron Age and it presents a potentially useful (yet currently overlooked) method for dating salt production activities. Samples were selected for radiocarbon and OSL dating from the Marsal transect core samples based on lithostratigraphy, organic matter content and the relationship between floodplain sediments and briquetage. Inorganic sediments were OSL dated using the single-aliquot regenerative-dose (SAR) method outlined in Murray and Wintle (2000). Calibrations and checks were performed at each stage in the procedure to ensure confidence in the dates obtained (e.g. Adamiec and Aitken, 1998; Armitage and Bailey, 2005; Duller, 2003; Murray and Wintle, 2000; Prescott and Hutton, 1988).

Sediments immediately underlying the briquetage deposit, in addition to the base and top of this deposit, were radiocarbon and OSL dated to determine the onset and duration of briquetage accumulation (and hence salt production) at this locality (Figure 2). Adjacent alluvial sediments were dated to assess the temporal and stratigraphic relationship between briquetage accumulation and floodplain development. There was good overall correspondence between the dates produced, adding further confidence to the results obtained. Uninterrupted and relatively rapid deposition of fine-grained sediments has resulted in successful OSL dating of floodplain deposits at this locality. The resulting chronology is based on eight radiocarbon dates and ten OSL dates (Table 1).

caption.p: AMS radiocarbon dates and OSL dates obtained from borehole core samples at Salonnes (BH2, BH15) and Marsal (BH17, BH22, BH24, BH25, BH27, BH32).

sec.p: At Salonnes, preliminary interpretation of lithostratigraphic and palynological data was used to identify event horizons containing material suitable for radiocarbon dating. The resulting dates were used to test hypotheses relating to these events and to place the Salonnes palaeoenvironmental record within the wider sedimentary and archaeological context of the valley. They were also obtained to test the temporal and stratigraphic relationship between BH15 and the adjacent radiocarbon dated BH2. The chronology at this site is based on six radiocarbon dates (Table 1). All radiocarbon dates in this study were calibrated using OxCal 4.1 (Bronk Ramsey, 2001, 2009a, 2009b) and the INTCAL04 calibration curve (Reimer et al., 2004). Date ranges have been calculated using the maximum intercept method and are quoted at two-sigma (95.4%) confidence. All dates are given in calibrated years before present (BP) unless otherwise stated.

sec.title: Sedimentary history
sec.p: Figures 2 and 3 show the cross-valley sediment profile and chronology from Marsal and Salonnes respectively. Figure 3 also shows the results of detailed lithostratigraphic analyses of BH15 from which event horizons have been identified. The Salonnes profile is typical of stratigraphy identified elsewhere on the floodplain. Five alternating phases of erosion and deposition have consistently been identified in the Holocene sedimentary record (Green et al., 2005; Riddiford, 2010) (Figure 4a): Erosional Phase 1 was characterised by incision into Pleistocene sand and gravel, forming a channel(s) cut into this sediment body and creating at least one terrace, evident on the north of the floodplain at Marsal (Figure 2). These events probably occurred in response to rapid climate change at the Lateglacial–Holocene transition (~11,500–11,250 BP) (Antoine et al., 2003). This was followed by infilling of the Lateglacial–Holocene channel(s) during Depositional Phase 1. Repeated floodplain aggradation and incision occurred between 6900–6690 BP (Wk-21282) and ~3200 BP at Marsal and between 6260–5990 BP (SUERC-18402) and ~3200 BP at Salonnes, resulting in a valley-wide hiatus (Erosional Phase 2). Soil formed on the gravel terrace at Marsal during this time.

(b) Summary of Marsal and Salonnes pollen records and vegetation change against the event stratigraphy identified from the Marsal and Salonnes palaeoenvironmental records. The event boundaries overlap due to large error ranges, nevertheless there does appear to be concordance between the apparent timing of events. All Salonnes LPAZ boundaries are dated using radiocarbon and modelled ages, with the exception of LPAZ S1 and LPAZ S1-S2, which have been inferred based on event stratigraphy. The first occurrence of Fagus pollen is indicated.

sec.p: Salt production began during Depositional Phase 2, which was characterised by the onset of sparsely organic silt deposition closely followed by the first occurrence of briquetage throughout the study area. The detailed cross-valley transect at Marsal allows the stratigraphic relationship between natural floodplain deposits and salt archaeology (briquetage) derived from nearby salt workshops to be investigated (Figures 1 and 2). Sedimentary and dating evidence indicates that this archaeology began to accumulate on the terrace surface, burying the palaeosol and then spreading out onto the adjacent floodplain over time. OSL dating suggests that this began in 3650–3170 BP (ML9) during the mid-to-late Bronze Age and this is supported by radiocarbon and OSL dating of the underlying palaeosol (Figure 2). However, relative and radiocarbon dating of the salt workshops based on pottery and charcoal associated with briquetage debris have consistently produced Iron Age dates in the range of ~800–400 bc (~2750–2350 BP) (Olivier, 2009). Current research in the Seille Valley (led by Olivier) is attempting to elucidate this apparent discrepancy through targeted excavation of specific areas of the floodplain where there is possible evidence for mid-to-late Bronze Age salt production activities.

This ongoing investigation includes the area adjacent to the Marsal transect (Figures 1 and 2), where overlapping ages from the base of the briquetage deposit indicate rapid lateral briquetage accumulation, increasing from ~11–13 cm/yr between the mid- Bronze Age and early Iron Age (BH25 to BH17) to ~124–155 cm/yr following the establishment of early Iron Age salt production (BH17 to BH32). Briquetage accumulated faster than the adjacent alluvium throughout this time (~0.23–0.26 cm/yr in BH17 c.f. ~0.04–0.09 cm/yr in BH22), resulting in an artificially raised area on the floodplain. A river channel was present to the south of the terrace during this briquetage accumulation, as evident from the discrepancy in dates between the briquetage and alluvium together with the occurrence of scattered briquetage to the south of the main deposit (Figure 2). As briquetage spread out onto the floodplain it is likely that the channel became blocked and moved progressively further south until it was abandoned and relocated towards the northern edge of the floodplain where a palaeochannel dating from 2130–1900 BP (Wk-21287: BH27) has been identified. Flooding would have increased as a result. Salt production continued, possibly without interruption, throughout Depositional Phase 2, but the briquetage method was replaced by new techniques in about ad 50 (Decomps, 2003; Multhauf, 1978).

Downstream at Salonnes there is evidence for environmental disturbance between 3210–2970 BP (SUERC-18403) and ~2900–2700 BP, when sand horizons containing Bythinia and freshwater mussel shells indicate a period of increased flood frequency and sediment accumulation (Figure 3). This was potentially linked to salt production and/or regional climatic change, which occurred at around this time (Berglund, 2003). During the early Iron Age flood frequency was low at this locality but intensification of production in the 2nd–1st centuries bc coincided with the onset of deposition of eroded sediments (scattered granules of unidentified white lithology, possibly limestone, accompanied by an increase in magnetic susceptibility from ~8 to 50 SI) in ~2250–2050 BP (Figure 3). These conditions persisted until 1060–930 BP (SUERC-18404) when peaty silt began to accumulate across the floodplain (Depositional Phase 3). This coincided with infilling of the northern palaeochannel at Marsal in 1060–930 BP (Wk-21284), suggesting that these events were related. This well-dated sedimentary record provides clear evidence for widespread episodic alteration to the local fluvial regime in the Seille Valley from the Bronze Age onward, which continued until the 19th century when the floodplain was drained and the river canalised (Decomps, 2003).

sec.title: Vegetation change and human-impact history
sec.p: The results of pollen analyses from Marsal and Salonnes are presented in Figures 5 and 6. These allow the development of favourable conditions for salt production and the human–environment relationship of this activity to be examined. The allochothonous nature of the floodplain sediments and differential pollen preservation that characterise alluvial environments do not appear to have greatly affected the local and regional pollen record in the Seille Valley. Common features of early- to mid-Holocene European pollen records, such as initial dominance of Pinus followed by the development of mixed Quercus woodland (Bell and Walker, 1992; Birks, 1986b; Digerfeldt et al., 1997), are evident and there is clear concordance with general vegetation trends identified from studies in the Vosges Mountains (Janssen, 1996). The dominance of pollen derived from floodplain and channel vegetation, and the low arboreal component during the early to mid Holocene, are common features of alluvial pollen records (Bell and Walker, 1992; Birks, 1986b; Brown, 1997; Scaife and Burrin, 1992). Local dryland vegetation is nevertheless also represented in the Seille Valley records and general trends are clearly evident (Figure 4b).

sec.title: Depositional Phase 1
sec.p: Depositional Phase 1 was initially characterised by the presence of Pinus woodland on the valley sides, and saltmarsh, backswamps and shallow vegetated river channels on the floodplain at Marsal and Salonnes (LPAZ M1 and LPAZ S1). Mixed deciduous forest replaced Pinus woodland prior to 8980–8640 BP (SUERC-17757) at Salonnes. The presence of Fagus in the Salonnes and Marsal pollen records at this time is unexpected given that the earliest published pollen record from this region is ~7200 BP at Kastelberg, Vosges (De Valk, 1981). Nevertheless, Fagus had clearly become established in the Seille Valley by 9000 BP.

Backswamp and shallow vegetated freshwater channels continued to be present at this time, whilst saltmarsh expanded and dry, bare and saline conditions developed at the beginning of LPAZ M2 (Figure 5) and LPAZ S2 (Figure 6): Saltmarsh taxa Plantago coronopus and Polygonum aviculare appear for the first time alongside dry, bare and/or disturbed ground taxa Rumex obtusifoilus and R. acetosella at Salonnes. Chenopodiaceae and Aster type pollen also increased at both Marsal and Salonnes and this is likely to represent the expansion of locally occurring species Salicornia ramosissima, Aster maritima, and/or the endemic S. vecensis and S. herbacca. These occur on dry saline silt on river banks and in saltmarshes (Duvigneaud, 1967). This was followed by evidence for opening up of the woodland cover towards the end of this phase at Salonnes, during the early Neolithic period (~7150–6850 BP): Alnus, Betula and Quercus pollen decrease and Poaceae and Cereal type pollen increase.

sec.title: Erosional Phase 2
sec.p: Erosional Phase 2 occurred at the boundary between LPAZ S2 and LPAZ S3 at Salonnes and at 197.7 m a.s.l. in LPAZ M2 at Marsal. It is clearly evident in both records from the abrupt change in pollen percentages and concentrations accompanied by the appearance of new taxa, which signal the beginning of the next phase.

sec.title: Depositional Phase 2
sec.p: Depositional Phase 2 was initially characterised by the presence of saltmarsh and a river channel(s) in proximity to Marsal (LPAZ M2), followed by a brief period of inundation and/or waterlogging from 198.1 m a.s.l. to the top of LPAZ M2 (~3410–2950 BP). This is evident from an increase in aquatic taxa and overall pollen concentration. At Salonnes the temporary decrease in saltmarsh, evident from the lower percentage and concentration of Chenopodiaceae and Aster type pollen at the beginning of LPAZ S3 (Figure 6; Riddiford, 2010), may similarly have arisen from an influx of freshwater.

This was followed by evidence for woodland clearance in the Salonnes pollen record and an increase in taxa associated with agriculture, disturbed and/or bare ground and saltmarsh (e.g. Centaurea cyanus, Chenopodiaceae) at both localities. At Marsal this was accompanied by an increase in unidentifiable degraded pollen and overall decrease in pollen concentration in LPAZ M3, probably due to increased sedimentation rate which diluted the signal from ~3410 to 2950 BP onwards. This potentially occurred in response to increased intensity of salt production activities in the local area, which is likely to have created extensive bare hypersaline areas on the floodplain susceptible to erosion (c.f. Lee, 1977). Pollen concentration remains low in LPAZ M4, probably due to increased disturbance of the floodplain following the onset of industrial-scale salt production, as indicated by an accompanying peak in microscopic charred fragments (Figure 5).

The growing intensity of Iron Age salt production evident in the archaeological record is similarly reflected in the palaeoenvironmental record at Salonnes where there is evidence for increased intensity of human activities in ~2450–2200 BP (Figure 6: 197 m a.s.l.). Woodland removal appears to have occurred at this time and there was an expansion in agriculture (arboreal pollen decreases and there is an increase in agricultural-indicator taxa). This probably reflects utilisation of the local woodland for fuel by the salt industry and opening up of land for agriculture and settlement: the scale of salt production at this time would have required an enormous quantity of fuel and a large workforce, although these are difficult to quantify. It is probable that woodland management took place but it is not possible to detect this in the pollen records. Cyperaceae and Poaceae pollen concentrations also notably increase at this time (Riddiford, 2010), indicating marsh expansion. This was followed by the beginning of the most intensive phase of industrial-scale production, which corresponds to the LPAZ S3-S4a boundary (~2250–2050 BP). This was characterised by an overall decrease in pollen concentration, probably due to the influx of eroded sediment to this site. There is an increase in degraded Chenopodiaceae, Lactuceae and Poaceae pollen grains towards the top of LPAZ S4a (Riddiford, 2010), which strongly suggests a floodplain source, probably from the vicinity of salt workshops.

Stable environmental conditions appear to have returned ~ad 500–600 to ~ad 890–1020 (198.2–198.6 m a.s.l.), as indicated by an increase in overall pollen concentration and recovery of taxa such as Fagus, Quercus, Cereal type, Cyperaceae and Sinapis type. There was an open landscape at this time comprising mixed Fagus-Quercus woodland and arable agriculture. Saltmarsh had contracted whilst freshwater marsh continued to be present on the floodplain.

sec.title: Depositional Phase 3
sec.p: Depositional Phase 3 was initially characterised by a substantial increase in freshwater marsh, which largely replaced saltmarsh, and proximity to a river channel(s) and/or peaty pools at Salonnes (Sparganium type and Typha type pollen increase and Chenopodiaceae pollen decreases). This was followed by an increase in standing water (such as peaty pools and/or river and stream channels) on the floodplain at the beginning of LPAZ S5 (~ad 1350–1550). Drier conditions subsequently developed and arable agriculture expanded in ~ad 1350–1450 (199.8 m a.s.l.), as indicated by the decrease in Sparganium type and Typha type pollen and increase in agricultural-indicator taxa. This potentially reflects the onset of river management and marsh drainage during the Medieval Period (Decomps, 2003). From ~ad 1450–1850 onwards (LPAZ S6) there is clear evidence for development of an open agricultural landscape (pastural and arable) similar to that evident today, with predominantly dry floodplain conditions and infrequent flooding. The diversity of pollen taxa is much lower than previously and is dominated by Pinus, Cyperaceae, Lactuceae, Poaceae and Sinapis type. Nineteenth Century drainage of the floodplain is evident in reductions to Cyperaceae, Sparganium type and Typha type pollen concentrations whist the increase in Pinus pollen reflects the establishment of plantations in uplands of the Vosges Mountains from ~ad 1600 onwards (Janssen, 1996; Figure 7).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Until now, little has been known about the Holocene fluvial and vegetation history of this region of France, largely because sedimentological studies have focused on the Lateglacial period (e.g. Antoine et al., 2003; Cordier et al., 2006) and it has been assumed that ‘because of intensive agriculture, no proper [pollen] sites are available from Lorraine and the Alsace’ (Janssen, 1996: 585). The results of this study, however, demonstrate that palynological analysis of alluvial sediments in this region is a feasible and worthwhile exercise when undertaken as part of a wider integrated study encompassing sedimentology, archaeology and a robust chronological framework.

Broadly speaking, the Holocene fluvial and vegetation history of the Seille Valley is typical of many northwest and central European lowland floodplains (Figure 7). Erosional Phase 1 and Depositional Phase 1 (Figure 4) are characteristic of early- to mid-Holocene palaeohydrological changes reconstructed from European floodplain records (Antoine et al., 2003; Bell and Walker, 1992; Brown et al., 1994; Collins et al., 2006; Cordier et al., 2006; Hoffmann et al., 2007; Huhmann et al., 2003; Kaase et al., 1995; Kalis et al., 2003; Lewis et al, 2001; Pastre et al., 2003; Scaife and Burrin, 1992; Sidell et al., 2000; Tebbens et al., 1999). The Seille Valley record also provides important information about the environmental and social history of this region.

It has produced the earliest northerly Holocene record of Fagus pollen to date, at least 2000 years earlier than the oldest published record from the Vosges (~7200 BP; De Valk, 1981). This challenges the current interpretation proposed by Magri et al. (2006), which suggests that Fagus initially migrated to the Vosges from a Lateglacial refuge in the Swiss mountains in ~8900 BP (Magri et al., 2006). The Seille Valley record indicates that Fagus was already established in the lowlands of the Vosges Mountains at this time. European mountain chains are believed to have played an essential role in facilitating the postglacial spread of this taxon (Magri et al., 2006) and it is therefore possible that the Vosges were an important, yet currently overlooked, Lateglacial refuge, which played an important role in the northward (and southern?) expansion of Fagus during the early to mid Holocene.

The Seille Valley record has also provided an insight into the development of favourable conditions for salt production. Saltmarsh was present on the floodplain from the early Holocene onwards and brine springs are likely to have attracted people to the area. Well-drained loessic soils made this a favourable location for early agriculture and the pollen record suggests that people were practicing agriculture at Salonnes in the early Neolithic. Thus small-scale harvesting of salt for personal dietary needs probably took place from at least the Neolithic onwards. However the hiatus in the sedimentary record, which lasts for much of the Neolithic and Bronze Age (Erosional Phase 2), has prevented identification of this. The hiatus reflects a regional shift towards increased flooding, aggradation and incision, and widespread change in river behaviour, which reached its maximum extent between ~6000 and ~3000 BP (Figure 7) (Berglund, 2003; Collins et al., 2006).

A colder and/or moister climate developed ~3500 BP (Magny, 2004; Zolitschka et al., 2003). The number and size of proposed European centres employing the briquetage technique are thought to have increased at around this time (Bizien-Jaglin, 1995; Ciobanu, 2006; Fawn et al., 1990; Fielding, 2005b; Garner, 2005; Jodlowski, 1975; Jülich, 2005; Nenquin, 1961; Tessier, 1975), although there are few confirmed sites in northwest Europe. The research presented here highlights the potential of using palaeoenvironmental records to detect evidence for early salt production activities and to provide a valuable insight into the relationship between environmental change and prehistoric salt production. The Seille Valley palaeoenvironmental record suggests that salt production was underway by the mid to late Bronze Age, at least 400–600 years earlier than implied by the archaeological record. This discrepancy in chronologies has potentially arisen because Bronze Age salt archaeology has been buried by substantial accumulations of Iron Age briquetage at localities such as Marsal and has not therefore been identified. Resolving this question is central to ongoing investigations and it will prove crucial to the interpretation of evidence for environmental change in the Seille Valley during the mid to late Bronze Age, when continuous alluviation began (~3400–3220 BP: Depositional Phase 2).

There was a widespread increase in flooding and alluviation in much of central and northwest Europe ~3250–3050 BP onwards (Magny, 2004) (Figure 7). This is thought to have been in response to regional climatic change rendering fluvial systems more sensitive to human activities coupled with increased intensity of agriculture and deforestation (Berglund, 2003; Burrin and Scaife, 1984; Collins et al., 2006; Hoffmann et al., 2007; Houben et al., 2006; Kalis et al., 2003; Leroux et al., 2008; Zolitschka et al., 2003). The results presented here suggest that salt production in the Seille Valley increasingly contributed to flooding and alluviation as the scale and intensity of this activity grew: following climatic deterioration ~3500 BP (Magny, 2004; Zolitschka et al., 2003), at the beginning of Depositional Phase 2, there appears to have been waterlogging, disturbance of the floodplain and increased areas of bare saline ground susceptible to erosion at Marsal (Figure 5) coupled with increased flooding downstream at Salonnes (Figures 1 and 3). This was accompanied by a reduction in dry saline conditions, evident from a decrease in Cheonopodiaceae pollen percentage and concentration at Marsal (Figure 5) and Salonnes (Riddiford, 2010). This flooding was potentially linked to salt production activities and channel blockage upstream at Marsal (identified from sedimentary and dating evidence in the cross-valley transect: Figure 2), where briquetage accumulation appears to have directly impacted on the fluvial regime.

Emergence of industrial-scale production at the beginning of the Iron Age coincided with a period of European-wide expansion and intensification of salt production and further climatic deterioration ~2800 BP (Berglund, 2003; Magny, 2004). However, there is no evidence for increased flooding in the Seille Valley at this time. This potentially reflects the implementation of river management to mitigate periods of increased flood frequency, which would have been necessary to avoid inundation of workshop areas, as dry conditions are essential to maintain furnace fires used to harvest salt (Fawn et al., 1990; Fielding, 2005a, 2005b, 2005c). Ditches and wells have been identified at salt workshops in the Seille Valley (Olivier, 2004). The late Iron Age channel at Marsal (Figure 2) became established in 2130–1900 BP (Wk-21287), during the most intensive phase of production (Olivier, 2009; Olivier and Kovacik, 2006). As such, it probably represents a man-made drainage feature used to reduce flooding at this locality. Briquetage may also have been used to create artificially raised working surfaces to protect sites during flood events: substantial accumulations of briquetage beneath the modern towns of Marsal, Moyenvic and Vic-sur-Seille (Figure 1) resulted from in situ deposition throughout the Iron Age industrial period (Olivier and Kovacik, 2006, 2007).

Industrial-scale activities directly contributed to alluviation during the Iron Age and deposition of eroded floodplain sediments peaked immediately following the most intensive (late Iron Age) phase (Figure 3). Human activities on the valley sides, such as settlement, woodland clearance/management and agriculture, are likely to have contributed significantly to floodplain alluviation by (for example) increasing run-off and supplying colluvium to the system. This continued into the Medieval Period (Depositional Phase 3), when climatic amelioration in ~ad 750–1300 (the ‘Medieval Warm Period’ (Bell and Walker, 1992)) appears to have coincided with drier floodplain conditions at Salonnes and infilling of the northern palaeochannel at Marsal, probably due to lowering of the groundwater level and reduced flooding. Reduction in water-table levels occurred throughout Europe at this time (Figure 7). This was replaced by widespread waterlogging of the Seille Valley floodplain and marsh development from ~ad 850–1000 onwards due to extensive modification of the local fluvial regime. This included construction of artificial salt lakes for aquaculture at Deuze, drainage of the floodplain, river management, and the deliberate flooding of areas around Marsal, Vic-sur-Seille and Metz for defensive purposes during periods of conflict over ownership of the salt industry (Decomps, 2003; Multhauf, 1978). Marsh conditions persisted until the 19th century, when the floodplain was drained and the river was canalised. Socioeconomic and political factors therefore appear to have played a leading role in human activities and impacts on the landscape from at least the Medieval Period, and probably earlier, in the Seille Valley.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results presented here have provided new insights into the Holocene environmental and social history of this previously poorly studied region of France. They have demonstrated that there are suitable sites for pollen analysis in Lorraine and the Alsace and have highlighted the importance of the region for advancing knowledge about the postglacial re-colonisation of taxa such as Fagus. This study is one of the first of its kind to investigate the environmental history of a European salt production site and the human–environment relationship of this activity. The scale and intensity of salt production in the Seille Valley also makes it extremely important for elucidating the relationship between industrial-scale activities and changes in the natural environment in later prehistory. The application of OSL and radiocarbon dating outlined here is a potentially important new approach for dating these sites. The possibility of Bronze Age salt production in the Seille Valley is a significant finding given that there are so few confirmed sites dating to this period. It is therefore essential to resolve differences in the chronology of salt production identified in the environmental and archaeological records outlined here, and this is the focus of ongoing investigations. The relationship between salt production and palaeohydrology has also emerged as an important theme. The results suggest that the development of industrial salt production had a major impact on the hydrological regime of the valley and its sedimentological history, with evidence for accelerated alluviation arising from floodplain erosion at production sites and modification of the local fluvial regime due to briquetage accumulation on the floodplain and possible river management. This research provides an important insight into the environmental implications of early industrial activities.
